ModuleInstance.ModuleInstanceDescription:
DEVP0038 will give you a detailed introduction to  key economic concepts, theories and tools applied to problem diagnosis and policy making in urbanisation and development in developing countries. Its theoretical framework integrates  classical economic theory, the New Economic Geography, Core-Periphery, Global Commodity Chains and World City Networks, Activist vs Austerity Policies, The Economics of Manipulation, and the Digital Economy.

Key topics are: prospects for urbanisation and development (economic growth, social justice and environmental sustainability); the market economy and market forces; international trade and investment; exourbanisation ; role of the state in development; trends in urbanisation and the effects of policies;  migration; urban agglomeration economies and diseconomies; cities and structural adjustment; neo-liberalism and austerity; roles of multilateral development agencies and foreign aid; role of economic analysis in urban development; measuring causes and effects; functioning of global capitalism as based  on transnational economic networks and translocally-linked urban centres ( including China’s Belt and Road Initiative), and the digital economy as a key part of the global economy and therefore of patterns of urbanisation.

On completion you will have a solid grasp of economic concepts, theories and tools that may be applied to the contemporary analysis and management of urbanisation as a global dimension; will be able to understand and critical analysing  the key concepts of contemporary urbanisation and development, agglomeration economies and diseconomies, the global economy  and its relations with national economies; describe and understand the contemporary synergies (international, regional and national) of urbanisation and development; understand and explain the principal types of state intervention in the urban sector; understand the dynamic of the interaction between agglomeration economies, capital accumulation, economic growth, and levels of social justice and environmental sustainability and, finally, how global capitalism affects global urbanisation and development.
